[Music]
Welcome back to Practically Intelligent.
As always, we have your host here. My name is Sonan Osar, and with me as always is the amazing OE. Today, we are talking to... We're very excited about this today. We're talking to Rajiv Shah. Rajiv has been... he's worked all over the place. He's been at DataRobot, he's been at Hugging Face. He's currently at Snowflake, helping enterprise customers and all kinds of customers make use out of their AI and their data as effectively and as efficiently as possible. So, we have a great interview. To what was... So, we've already recorded the interview, of course, but actually, tell what was your favorite part of the interview, because I think I have three or four different parts, but I'm curious what you thought.
I think this broadly just became a great reflection on the state of open source and what that actually means and predictions for where it's going. I think we get into a little bit of licensing and governance, but I think we actually sort of talk about sort of the business model at the end, and that was pretty fun to just project out in the future a little bit, um, and talk about some of the implications of this and where Rajiv sees it's going. What about you?
Yeah, uh, agreed. And for anyone who doesn't actually know who Rajiv is, you should look him up, and obviously, we'll have links to to look more into him, because he's on social media. He... he's out there. His presence in the community is extremely vibrant, right? He's... he's such a good teacher. He's so good at talking about these kinds of concepts, and I think that really comes through. So, honestly, I'm very excited for everyone to hear this interview, because it's... it's one of the... it's one of the times where I, as an instructor, feel really humble to be like, "Wow, like this is... this is exactly how I wish I could be presenting myself all the time." So, uh, let's... let's just dive in, shall we? Let's do it.
Rajiv, thank you so much for being with us on Practically Intelligent. Uh, we have a lot to talk about, and I'm really excited to get through everything on our... on our list with you. But I... I want to start with some level setting. So, you know, longtime listeners of our show will remember that the... the landscape and trend of LLMs, particularly open source LLMs, for the past few years at least, has been large to huge companies, you know, Google's, the Meta's, they're putting out... they're producing open source LLMs or close source LLMs, they're producing data sets, they're producing a lot of academic material, and smaller to medium-sized businesses act more as the consumer, right? They're consuming the models, the data sets, the... the academic research, and then they're fine-tuning it, remixing it for their own purposes. And that... that's been the general trend for... for a while now. But I... I want to ask you just kind of straight up: is that still the trend, or... or what trends are you seeing now in 2024 about open source LLMs that we should be thinking about?
Yeah, so that gets it... you know, how do we get open source models, where do they come from? And I think what you're talking about is kind of a new phenomenon that we've had, if you consider the last 10 or 20 years of machine learning, where we see all these corporate research labs, right? The... the Google Deep Minds, right? The... the, um, the Google, the Meta Labs, that they're the ones that are predominantly dominating not only the creation of the open source models that we have, but also the academic literature as well. They're right, they're driving what's happening at these academic conferences with that. So, there's a whole, like, political economy of, like, are they dominating research like that? But to your trend in terms of, like, who's developing the open source models that lots of us kind of that are lower down that are using them, yes, those research labs are driving a lot of them, especially where the amount of compute and the amount of data matters for the models. This is why you see the most with the large language models. Now, there's still lots of universities that are busy kind of sharing out their models.
Nowadays, one of the recent trends we've had in the last two years is just the amount of VC money that's flooding in, where you have so many startups now that are armed with a huge amount of cloud credits. We can talk about the nuances of, right, Nvidia funding its own cloud credits for companies that it's going back into it, but you also have some smaller companies nowadays that are building open source to get market share, to get noticed like that, right? It's become not only about kind of sharing for academic knowledge, but, "Hey, is this a way that I can get publicity, right?" And, right, you could just watch how the folks at Mistral, for example, do their marketing as a great example of, like, how they've been creative to make sure a little company of, right, 20-odd people living out in France is being able to get worldwide attention for the models that they're building.
Yeah, I'm... I'm immediately glad you brought that up, because in... in a lot of my own kind of consulting and lectures, when... when I talk about open source, you know, a lot of the talk track is kind of, to your point, relatively old, if you consider the past few decades old, right? You know, you... you build off open source models, you have to add your own data to it, you have to define your task pretty clearly and succinctly and and test it and iterate on it. But to your point, in the last couple of years, there's been a little bit more of a... of an entrance to the phenomenon of using open source models, not necessarily to solve an internal task or even a task we product, but sometimes more often than not for the purposes of making a splash and getting known and and saying, "We built a model that can do X, Y, and Z," you know? And it's not even just companies you've heard of, like, like, like Mistral or or Meta or Google, even smaller companies who are... are, you know, on their own face, an eval company or an Ops company, they will make efforts to... to make news waves about, like, "We built a data set that can detect or that can be used to build models to detect, you know, X, Y, and Z," and and that is used as marketing, as PR, as inbound leads for their own, uh, for their own needs, you know, once they arrive, they say, "Yes, and that's all part of our product that costs, you know, X months, X dollar a month per person, per seat, per... per user," or whatever that is. So, to that end, how does that affect the kind of supply demand, the growth of open source, and not just models and data sets, but as you kind of hinted at, how does that also affect the growth and supply of of tooling and and and Ops-oriented companies in the LLM space?
Yeah, well, so I'm going to give a little bit of a step back and give a little bit of a historical answer. Like, when I started analytics 10 years ago, right, you would have to go and pay for IBM's SPSS, or you'd have to go pay for SAS if you're an enterprise if you wanted to do analytics. Like, this idea of open source analytics and models really wasn't around. There was a small crew of, like, our people, but it wasn't until about the last 10 years what we've seen this boom in open-source tooling for analytics. Now, this movement around the tooling for analytics has moved slow. You can think of things like Scikit-learn that have slowly year-over-year developed. Companies have helped paced it at different points there, but really kind of what's blown up in the last two years is the open source models in the NLP space, because we've always been able to build models. I could build a Titanic model and share it with the world, but no one cares, right? Similar, I could have an churn model for my company, no one else is going to care, because it's really specific to that problem. And what's happened is we've been able to build models for machine learning. We saw this first in vision, where it had a little bit of an impact, where we had general models, but we've really seen this in the NLP space, where the model that I build, because, right, I've... I've massed, right, trillions of tokens and an enormous amount of language and really is a robust understanding of language, like that, that I can use it, but I can pass it to the company down the street, and they can find a use for it as well. And so, when we talk about this, right, there's a small subset really of all the machine learning models that are out there that are really worthwhile to have an open source model that you can get attention for doing that, and that's because they're solving these very generalized problems, largely around language like that. So, to... to give the landscape, like, it's really only a small subset of models. We... we... it feels like, because we see it all the time, but if you talk to data scientists that work inside enterprises, right, most of the modeling they're doing is not with generative AI, right? 80, 90% of those tasks are still traditional kind of machine learning models. So, there is kind of this small set of models, though, that you talked about that are widely used, right? I... I built a new entity, um, uh, text U entity recognition, right? I... I can better it grabbing private data or grabbing company data out of text than anybody else, and I could share that out, let everybody else know, right? Put some benchmark scores out there on the website, so people know, right? Maybe have a... a small version of the model that people can demo like that and use as as a marketing piece like that, and that's all a pretty new thing to be able to kind of do all of that piece.
Yeah, and and you actually, you're starting to talk about something else that we... we have touched on, uh, on the show before. Actually, previously, we... we've had, um, Don Farmer on the show, who... who was the face of of E13 for many years, and and and this kind of evolution, to your point, of traditional, classical machine learning analytics, data science, whatever word you'd like to ATT to whatever task you're doing, to this kind of new age, quote unquote, of generative AI. And and to your point again, as a consultant myself, I... I often get asked to... to build models, and to the first thing in my head is like, "We don't need generative AI to solve this task," right? You're talking about pretty basic classification. Now, will I potentially try to use an LLM like Bert, who is not technically generative? Sure, but that... that idea that generative AI is here to effectively be the panacea that we've all been waiting for in machine learning, that's an idea that I think has been thoroughly, if not debunked, at least it has never been really proven to any extent to say, "This is actually the thing that everyone should be using," right?
You know, yeah, I... I think as a practicing data scientist, I think you could hold that. I think if you're a member of just the public that reads the AI news headlines like that, it's not obvious like that, right? Exact... the... the world itself has been so on the importance of generative AI, right? With, right, as we're talking here, right, the Nvidia presentation was just days ago, and the amount of attention that gets around that piece. So, so I... I know what you're saying, but, like, it's not the perception of everybody in the world that generative AI is only a small portion of... and you're right. I mean, and and again, to riff on that a little bit, the... you're absolutely right, because people who are listening to this, people, you know, us included, it's... it's pretty clear that, you know, what the... what the media is portraying, what the... what the mass public is consuming is very, very different from the kind of media diet that you might have or I might have or A might have. In fact, we did a whole episode on on tuning your media diet for this exact reason, for... for kind of avoiding the... these hype cycles. So, I guess what... one question off of that, um, is what kind of advice would you actually give to someone who... who might be thinking, "Oh, this is the first time I'm hearing that AI is not the answer to all of our problems?" What advice would you give that person, uh, to go seek different sources or to go seek different opinions? What would you tell that person?
I think the... the biggest lesson I like to kind of convey to people around this generative AI is a little bit about how the models work and what are the limitations, because it's so easy to use something like a ChatGPT and make it, which makes it feel like it's an authority. It has all of this knowledge. It makes it feel like it's really big and authoritative. You're just tiny, don't know anything, you should just be sucking in the knowledge like that, when the reality of it is, right, these machines, for example, they can... they've absorbed a large amount of material, but the outputs that they put out, right? And for, right, people like us that are in the field know this, right, that they're not truthful at all. They're just trying to guess what we like as the results, and they're not tied to any notion of physics, any notion of truth and facts. And this is something that I think is going to take a while for people to learn, no different than when the internet was first introduced or Wi-Fi or the iPhone. Like, all these technological things take a while for the heads to get inside people to get inside everyone, right? It literally takes, like, five to 10 years for people to absorb the idea that when they use these models, it's not going to be the entire truth, and they need to double-check it and not do that. And, right, like us at the leading edge, people are into this, this know all of this, but it's still taking a while to percolate, where you have the lawyer that's asking ChatGPT a question and cutting and pasting that into the brief, right? We still have far too many of those, and it's going to take a long time before people learn to stop doing that, and I'm not optimistic that we're going to solve the hallucination problem. So, I think we're going to have to educate humans are going to have to understand, just like when you search the internet, you know, there's trustworthy sites and there's trust sites that you can't trust. Same thing, people are going to have to learn when working with generative AI.
Speaking of cut and paste, Rajiv, you talked about, um, SPSS, SAS, the analex ecosystem, even, you know, if you look at prior machine learning companies and and productive companies, largely closed source, and we had an interesting open source versus close source moments just this past, uh, past year, I believe, this past, uh, spring, when the, uh, Alpaca team over mix of Stanford, Berkeley students, quantized and distilled, uh, the Llama model almost two weeks after, and it created some interesting side chatter. It wasn't certainly the main chatter, um, but about the future of open source, and was that right, um, because we all want powerful AI, um, in our hands to be able to be used for whatever our use case is, but was that dour, you know, the eus of open source? Was it truly open source? Tell us a little bit about, um, what you're seeing in licensing and how some of those debates are affecting the adoption of AI currently.
Yeah, and sorry for the history lessons, but I always have to do this is, you know, the world that we live in now with open source isn't the way the world has always been. I easily remember I worked as an IT administrator about... this is about 10, 15 years ago, open source was not liked at all. Like, nobody wanted people inside the IT of an organization using open source tooling. It was often seen as some full of kind of security holes, legal issues. You had to go through a bunch of paperwork to do that. Like, the world that we live in now, where open source feels very widely accepted, is not necessarily the way the world works, and part of it is that there's this very tenuous relationship here between licensing, copyright, and other kind of


Modalities that could affect open source.

So, if we start to take this apart, I think there's a couple of things. When we talk about large language models, they're ingesting large amounts of information that is copyrighted. Like, should they be able to transform and use papers, books by others, and transfer that into the large language model? That's an open question. Are the outputs that come out of this right? Is it... if you see this, especially with the image models, right? Are they outputting something that could be somebody else's artistic work or artistic style? That could be copyright.

On top of that, you have terms of service where, as I'm offering my model, I can give you specific requirements. So, it makes it a very much a tough web. A lot of these companies and folks like Meta have kind of played with this also, where there's been exceptions for doing things for research, for teaching, and education in copyright law, where, you know, if people are furthering the world that way, we're going to look, give them a little bit less of a hands-off versus if they're trying to make a buck. So, you've seen a lot of the research organizations try to use this research exception. And I mean, to me, it's not clear that, like, what Meta is doing is just pure research that's just trying to raise knowledge for everybody. They have a very commercial purpose as well when they release their Llama model to everybody to dominate the ecosystem where they can own, like, that. So, for me, it's not cut and dry, all these, like, issues that we have around open source. And I can easily see a world where we have one or two slight court cases, we have one or two security breaches with these large language models, and that could significantly reduce the ecosystem and the willingness of people to kind of share these models out like that.

Yeah, I mean, there's a lot to dissect in there, right? I mean, I... I... it's actually, I have to explain this to a lot of people where the, the idea that the purpose of what you're going to use a model for actually does affect how you interpret a license, right? Am I doing this, you know, I... I was a teacher for many years, you know, am I using this data for the purposes of a classroom, or am I gonna sell this thing eventually, right? Now, Meta doesn't, you know, at least not like OpenAI, doesn't really sell access to Llama, but that's a very viable business model for them going forward, should they choose to put Llama 3 behind a paywalled API. That's totally within their rights. And maybe Llama 2 for them is just a huge marketing, uh, uh, get to bring people there.

So, so to that end, when we're talking about the ecosystem of AI, and not just the ecosystem out there, but even within an organization and, uh, using open source softwares, oftentimes the quote-unquote solution, or at least the, the Band-Aid to the idea of, are we doing things right? Is this the right data to use? Is is tooling right? We we want something that can track provenance, we want something that can track copyright, we want something that can track PII. And and that's for data coming into the model and data for coming, data coming out of that model. But that itself can become a labyrinth, a behemoth.

So, I would love to hear, you know, coming from so many different environments, you know, Hugging Face, Snowflake, all these different experiences that you've had, what are some of the kind of concrete pieces of advice that you can give to someone who who's really thinking about this open-source ecosystem within their organization?

Yeah, and I'm going to tie this back to that first question around the licensing as well, because I think one of the things we're seeing with both on the tooling and the model side is that the creators can decide on the type of license they wanted. And for a long time, companies would either keep things proprietary themselves, they're going to charge for it, or they would use one of the classic open source licenses. Where nowadays, in the last couple of years, we found lots of companies are doing this middle ground where, okay, I'll let you use this model, but if your revenues are over $10 million a year, well, then you're going to pay, right? I mean, and you can see why, like, it gets some sense of fairness, or right, like, hey, you can use this, but if you're using this to mistreat women, that's that's banned, right? Like, you could see why people might want to. And as creators, they might want to to kind of be able to, right? They spent the effort building this thing, they want to tell people how to use it. But this is the other of it, especially if you're inside an Enterprise, and most Enterprises really do not want to get into litigation. They, they're risk-averse. They want their folks to use things that cause as little problems as possible. And it took a long time to get them to accept the open source licenses as well. I mean, again, like 15 years ago, most companies wouldn't let you use those open source licenses software inside a company. And so this is when it comes to thinking about your stack, that the easiest thing is, is if you can use that open source tooling now that has those licenses, like Apache MI2, because they have the least amount of restrictions, they're going to get past your Enterprise legal, your IT, you know, they're going to be widely supported by the community as well. So, I think that's an important starting point is when we're thinking about the licenses.

But I think the other piece is, we talk about the innovation in the space, and it's very hard to innovate faster than open source. You can do it for a little while, for a small amount of group, but I always like to think of it like, if you watch, ever watch the Tour de France or a bicycle race, where there's like a huge peloton that's always kind of moving, and you as a leader can go in front of it, you can go and maybe have a leading technology for a year or two, but if there's enough of a crowd that's interested, that's going to work together, crowdsource, cooperate, they're going to take you over. And this is where, you know, in the analytic tools stack, this is where I see over and over again, the open source just eating up kind of all those other little providers that are trying to build something differentiated.

Um, as well. And for those of you who don't know what a peloton is outside of the, the actual machine, it actually means, my best friend, uh, is a huge Tour de France fan, and, uh, apparently it literally means like a group of bikers in, in, in, uh, in a conglomerate. I did not know that before he told me. Um, so, okay, amazing.

The, I think the, the big question then, I mean, not even question, like, when you talk about, very first of all, like, probably the one of the clearest ways I've ever really heard explained, when you're talking about trying to get the, the licenses, you know, past your legal team or past your IT team, that for a lot of people, that's Step Zero, right? We're zero-indexing that's Step Zero, getting it past, you know, your, your internal team to say, go ahead, because once that happens, you now have to figure out, out, okay, well, what am I going to do with this model? Am I going to use it as is? Am I going to put more data into it through some fine-tuning process? What are the implications of that? You know, the, the easiest one that most people, maybe not most people, but a majority of people have probably been through, if they've been on an open source team or team that's used open source models at any point in the last several years, is, well, what, what kind of data are we allowed to fine-tune this model with? Can I use data from client A and client B in the same model? And that usually has to go past a round of IT and legal as well. I've done that countless times. So, is, are those just similar conversations to you, or is there something more to think about once you actually have have the thumbs up to use open source? So, what, what's the next line of of offense you have to get past?
